t: James 1
James,*p a servant of God and of the Lord Jesus Christ, to the twelve tribes which are scattered abroad, greeting.
My*p brethren, count it all joy when ye fall into divers temptations;
Knowing*p this, that the trying of your faith worketh patience.
But*p let patience have her perfect work, that ye may be perfect and entire, wanting nothing.
If*p any of you lack wisdom, let him ask of God, that giveth to all men liberally, and upbraideth not; and it shall be given him.
But*p let him ask in faith, nothing wavering. For he that wavereth is like a wave of the sea driven with the wind and tossed.
For*p let not that man think that he shall receive any thing of the Lord.
A*p double minded man is unstable in all his ways.
Let*p the brother of low degree rejoice in that he is exalted:
But*p the rich, in that he is made low: because as the flower of the grass he shall pass away.

For*p the sun is no sooner risen with a burning heat, but it withereth the grass, and the flower thereof falleth, and the grace of the fashion of it perisheth: so also shall the rich man fade away in his ways.
Blessed*p is the man that endureth temptation: for when he is tried, he shall receive the crown of life, which the Lord hath promised to them that love him.
Let*p no man say when he is tempted, I am tempted of God: for God cannot be tempted with evil, neither tempteth he any man:
But*p every man is tempted, when he is drawn away of his own lust, and enticed.
Then*p when lust hath conceived, it bringeth forth sin: and sin, when it is finished, bringeth forth death.
Do*p not err, my beloved brethren.
Every*p good gift and every perfect gift is from above, and cometh down from the Father of lights, with whom is no variableness, neither shadow of turning.
Of*p his own will begat he us with the word of truth, that we should be a kind of firstfruits of his creatures.
Wherefore,*p my beloved brethren, let every man be swift to hear, slow to speak, slow to wrath:
For*p the wrath of man worketh not the righteousness of God.
Wherefore*p lay apart all filthiness and superfluity of naughtiness, and receive with meekness the engrafted word, which is able to save your souls.
But*p be ye doers of the word, and not hearers only, deceiving your own selves.
For*p if any be a hearer of the word, and not a doer, he is like unto a man beholding his natural face in a glass:
For*p he beholdeth himself, and goeth his way, and straightway forgetteth what manner of man he was.
But*p whoso looketh into the perfect law of liberty, and continueth therein, he being not a forgetful hearer, but a doer of the work, this man shall be blessed in his deed.
If*p any man among you seem to be religious, and bridleth not his tongue, but deceiveth his own heart, this man's religion is vain.
Pure*p religion and undefiled before God and the Father is this, To visit the fatherless and widows in their affliction, and to keep himself unspotted from the world.
